animalOfTheDay.name: yellowfin tuna
facts: Their fins glow yellow when excited – a display during feeding frenzies.
Yellowfin tuna can reach 50 mph – among the fastest fish.
They hunt in coordinated schools, herding prey toward the surface.
Yellowfins maintain muscle temperature above water via specialized blood vessels.

calendar.name: wombat
facts: Wombats produce cube-shaped feces – unique among animals – to prevent rolling.
They dig complex burrows with multiple entrances and sleeping chambers.
Wombat rear hides have cartilage plates – blocking dingo bites when fleeing to tunnels.
They can run 25 mph despite stubby legs.

calendar.name: woodpecker
facts: Acorn woodpeckers drill thousands of holes to store acorns – 'granary trees'.
Woodpeckers have shock-absorbing skulls and compressible brain cases.
Their tongues wrap around skulls to cushion brains during pecking.
Pileated woodpeckers create rectangular holes in trees searching for ants.

calendar.name: woolly mammoth
facts: Woolly mammoths had fur up to 3 ft long and 4-inch fat layers for insulation.
Their curved tusks measured 16 ft – used for clearing snow to reach grass.
Mammoths survived on Wrangel Island until 1650 BCE – contemporary with Egyptian pyramids.
Permafrost-preserved mammoths provide DNA for de-extinction projects.

calendar.name: worm
facts: Earthworms have five hearts and breathe through skin.
They improve soil aeration – moving 20 tons of earth per acre annually.
Worms regenerate segments; some species regrow heads.
Charles Darwin studied earthworms for 40 years, calling them 'nature's ploughs'.

calendar.name: wren
facts: They sing at 10 notes/second – 10x faster than human speech.
Wrens roost communally in winter; 60+ birds huddle in nest boxes.
Eurasian wrens build dome-shaped nests with side entrances – males build multiple for females to choose.
The tiny winter wren weighs less than a nickel but sings loudly.

calendar.name: yak
facts: Their dung is dried and burned as fuel in treeless Himalayan regions.
Yaks survive at 20,000 ft – lungs and hearts 3x larger than cattle.
They grunt instead of mooing; 'yak' mimics their guttural sounds.
Yak milk is rich in butterfat – churned into butter tea in Tibet.

calendar.name: yellowfin tuna
facts: Yellowfins maintain muscle temperature above water via specialized blood vessels.
They hunt in coordinated schools, herding prey toward the surface.
Yellowfin tuna can reach 50 mph – among the fastest fish.
Their fins glow yellow when excited – a display during feeding frenzies.

randomAnimals.name: cat
facts: A group of cats is called a 'clowder' and a group of kittens is a 'kindle'.
Cats spend 70% of their lives sleeping, which is 13-16 hours a day.
Cats can rotate their ears 180 degrees to pinpoint sounds.
They have a third eyelid called a nictitating membrane for protection.

randomAnimals.name: mongoose
facts: Mongooses live in groups and communicate through a variety of vocalizations.
Some species, like the meerkat, are highly social and cooperative.
They have specialized acetylcholine receptors that make them resistant to snake venom.
Mongooses are famous for their ability to fight and kill venomous snakes.

randomAnimals.name: dalmatian
facts: They can have black or liver-colored spots, with black being more common.
Dalmatians have a natural affinity for horses and firehouses.
They were originally bred to run alongside horse-drawn carriages.
Dalmatian puppies are born completely white and develop spots as they grow.
